I have, but, you know, I find that we're really in an interesting time in television, because it used to be when I started in television, the black shows that were on, I personally don't feel like they aspired to be much more than, you know, placeholders.

But now you look at the landscape, you look at Bernie Mac, you look at the Dave Chappelle show, which may or may not come back, but at least you look at what he was trying to do, you look at ""Everybody Hates Chris,"" which is coming up, you look at our show, which I think is really aspiring to be a smart and clever and satirical show that--I don't think that we in particular--any one of these shows--has to do anything anymore just because the landscape has changed.
I think the opportunity is there for people who want to do something interesting, so I don't feel this great burden.
And I realize no matter what we do, there are going to be people who love the show and think it's genius.
There are going to be people who hate the show and think it's garbage.
So you really just have to sort of stand there and do what you're going to do and weather the storm, no matter which direction the winds are coming from.

And you say the series manages to show what is both troubling and inspiring about Africa.
How so?
Well, the thing about Africa is Africa is extraordinarily beautiful to the eye.
It's impossible for anyone other than a blind person to not be impressed by the sheer beauty of the country and of the animals and all of that.

But at the same time, Africa exists in - Africa is much like, as I say in the piece, is much like the American West was at - near the end of the 19th century, because on one end, it's as modern as anything else that exists in the world right now.
And on the other had, it's four or 500 years away from the present.
So you can, in Africa, you can be in a restaurant, a hotel, a library.
You can be having conversation with, you know, some African intellectuals or politicians and so on, and except for their that African accent, you could be anywhere else that's modern.
Then, you can do something that is very difficult to do in most places in the world that I know of.
You can get in your car, and in a half an hour, you can be in the Middle Ages.
So - and when you get out there in the bush, you know, people practice witchcraft and they believe it, real backward, if you want to call them backwards, tribal ideas that hold sway and all of that.
So Africa's in two different time periods at exactly the same time.

And that's why I would say it's very similar to the American Western, because what has interested people all over the world since the invention of the Western film was that on the one hand, these people could be in this little town, then they get on horseback and when they - the further away from town they get, the closer they get to a primitive, almost primeval kind of a situation where, you know, with these wild Indians, who can also be very majestic Indians, they can be benign and they can also be extraordinarily savage.

So in Africa, you have this combination of extraordinary brutality, extraordinary backwardness, inspiring vitality in terms of the morale that the people have about living and the enormous potential that any situation, when you encounter human beings, is, you know, that you can be elevated by the quality - by, you know, by - just by the human quality the people have.
